timeline.bodyText: It's always better to write these as KnownNotNull.VALUE.equals(itCouldMaybeByNull) In the case of enum values, prefer to put them on the left of the .equals(...).
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.bodyText:
As a comment on software construction - this looks mostly the same as an java.util.concurrent.AtomicReference.
More on the design sign, though, this might be a problematic construct. If actor A is writing to this, and actor B is reading from it, how will actor B know when to read? Even though you have an isSet(), actor B might ask at the wrong time.
To that point, the construct is inherently racy, which is why Java makes the AtomicReference as a thread-safe utility in the concurrency package.
One of the reasons Rx is popular for async programming is that it provides a way to chain together asynchronous work that depends on other asynchronous work.
I think the point of the AyncResult here is to decouple a chain of async work, from some synchronous work. But as above, this will destroy the dependency relationship, some event/trigger that notifies another component that the value state has changed.

replies.bodyText: By design, we want to enable plugin developers to put any plugin specific return values in an extension of this class.
replies.author: TrekSoft

replies.bodyText: My understanding is that, in general, Objects in the core library for a category should be non-final because, by nature, they are simply capturing what must be common across all plugins but we also expect there to be plugin specific values which we don't want put up at the core level but rather extended at the plugin implementation level.
replies.author: TrekSoft

replies.bodyText:
Open-closed principle (of SOLID) is:

software entities (classes, modules, functions, etc.) should be open for extension, but closed for modification

In practice, there are two principle ways to achieve extension points: inheritance, and composition. Software texts like Design Patterns tell us to prefer composition over inheritance.
Even so, there are benefits and drawbacks to using composition over inheritance, and both can be valuable tools.
Personally, the issues I have with inheritance are mostly a few:

Base classes grow over time, to include muddled concerns; AbstractFooBase (what is it?)
With a closed class implementation, you can encapsulate all of the policy and assumptions you hold about the function of the software. When you open a class, there is no guarantee that the derived class will meet all of these assumptions.

An interface has problem (2). An open non-abstract class is susceptible to (1). An abstract class may be used to enforce policy while offering means for extension/composition, and so contains partial mitigation to both (1) and (2).
Ref:

Delegation pattern
replies.author: jamesonwilliams
